Fig. 2 Fig. 3 NH3-TPD patterns of the catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR patterns of the catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Light-off curves of DCM catalytic degradation over the tested samples; (b) Light-off curves of CO2 and by-product yields over the tested samples. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XPS patterns of the catalysts (a C1s; b O1s; c Cl2p; d Ru3d; e Pd3d; f Pt4f). Fig. 8 Bimodal mesoporous TiO2 supported Pt, Pd and Ru catalysts and their catalytic performance and deactivation mechanism for catalytic combustion of Dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) Shuang Cao a b c Xiaoqi Fei a Yexuan Wen a b Zhuxing Sun a b Haiqiang Wang a b ⁎ Zhongbiao Wu a b a Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health, Ministry of Education, College of Environmental & Resource Sciences, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310058, PR China Key Laboratory of Environment Remediation and Ecological Health Ministry of Education College of Environmental & Resource Sciences Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310058 PR China b Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler & Furnace Flue Gas Pollution Control, Hangzhou 310058, PR China Zhejiang Provincial Engineering Research Center of Industrial Boiler & Furnace Flue Gas Pollution Control Hangzhou 310058 PR China c College of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, PR China College of Chemical and Biological Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Yuhangtang Road 866, Hangzhou 310058, PR China. Graphical abstract Pt-, Pd-, and Ru-doped bimodal mesoporous TiO2 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and applied to the catalytic combustion of dichloromethane (DCM). The Pd/TiO2 and Ru/TiO2 catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity. Total oxidation of DCM was obtained at 335°C with less undesired CO and byproducts (CxHyClz). A certain decrease in the selectivity of the Pd/TiO2 catalyst was observed in a long-term stability test, whereas Ru/TiO2 displayed appreciable stability. Pt/TiO2 was easily deactivated and showed the poorest performance for DCM decomposition. Deactivation of the catalysts was related to the deposition of carbon species and chlorine poisoning, whereby the active sites for DCM decomposition were occluded. Furthermore, the adsorption of chlorine species could change the chemical states of the Pd or Pt species and generate inactive species. Deactivation of the Ru/TiO2 catalyst was inhibited to some extent as carbon and chlorine species could be removed by RuO2. Moreover, the larger pore-size distribution of Ru/TiO2 was favorable for the desorption of by-products during DCM oxidation. Keywords Catalytic oxidation Chlorinated VOCs Deactivation Carbon species Chlorine poisoning 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) are widely used in industry and their release is considered as a severe environmental threat as they are harmful and hazardous to the environment and human health [1–4]. Catalytic oxidation is one of the most promising techniques for CVOCs abatement and has attracted increasing attention due to escalating air pollution [5–7]. At present, the synthesis of suitable catalysts is key for widespread CVOCs abatement by catalytic oxidation [8,9]. Noble metals are widely studied as promising catalysts for the catalytic combustion of CVOCs due to their high activity at low temperature. Pt, Pd, and Rh have received particular attention, where these metals have been supported on many transition metal oxides, such as Al2O3, CeO2, MgO, Al2O3-TiO2, Al2O3-CeO2, and TiO2-ZrO2 [10–15]. Previous studies have shown that the surface acidity of the catalysts is an important factor for the degradation for short-chain CVOCs [16]. TiO2 is one of the classical acid catalysts. A recent evaluation of Ru/TiO2 showed high activity and stability for DCM oxidation [17], attributed to the fast removal of the Cl species generated during DCM oxidation. The catalytic activity of Ru/TiO2 for DCM degradation encouraged us to probe the anti-poisoning mechanism of this kind of catalyst. Nanostructured porous materials are often employed as catalyst supports due to their high surface areas and large number of pores for dispersal of the active particles; these pores also favor the diffusion of gas reactants and products [17–21]. Kosuge [22] et al. investigated the dynamic adsorption/desorption behavior of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) for four kinds of mesoporous silicas and found that the pore structure had an effect on the VOC dynamic adsorption/desorption performance. Fiber-like silicas exhibited higher VOC adsorption capacity and easier desorption due to the formation of a bimodal pore system consisting of long, one-dimensional mesopore channels connected by complementary micropores. As reported by Yu [23], bimodal nanocrystalline mesoporous TiO2 powders prepared by a hydrothermal method showed high photocatalytic activity, where the activity more than three times higher than that of Degussa P25.This suggests that bimodal mesoporous TiO2 may be a promising material for the oxidation of CVOCs. In this study, Pt-, Pd-, and Ru-doped bimodal mesoporous TiO2 species were prepared as catalysts for the catalytic combustion of dichloromethane (DCM) as a model short-chain chlorinated VOCs. The DCM degradation efficiency, type and amount of byproducts, and degree of total oxidation on the as-synthesized catalysts and their long-term stability were investigated and compared. Moreover, the structural and surface chemical properties of these catalysts were characterized by XRD, BET, SEM, NH3-TPD, H2-TPR, and XPS methods. Focus is placed on the mechanism of deactivation of the catalysts during the catalytic combustion of DCM. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All reagents used in the present work were of analytical grade. Nano-sized anatase bimodal mesoporous TiO2 was prepared by a hydrothermal method described elsewhere [24,25]. The introduction of Pt, Pd, and Ru onto the TiO2 support was conducted by impregnating the titanium support with the required amount of Pt(NH3)4Cl2, Pd(NH3)4Cl2, and RuCl3. The targeted loading of noble metals was 1wt.%. The mixture was stirred for 6h, dried, and calcined at 450°C for 3h to obtain the final sample for further analysis and examination. The catalysts are designated as Pt/TiO2, Pd/TiO2, and Ru/TiO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction was used to analyze the crystal phases of the samples (XRD: X’Pert3 Powder, PANalytical B.V., Netherlands). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BET specific surface areas were obtained using a nitrogen adsorption apparatus (Beijing JWGB Sci. &Tech. Co., Ltd). All the samples were degassed at 200°C prior to the measurements. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a Hitachi SU 8010 apparatus to observe the morphologies of the catalysts powders. The surface properties and total density of states (DOS) distribution in the valence band of the samples were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy with Al Kα X-ray (hν=1486.6eV) radiation operated at 150W (XPS: Thermo ESCALAB 250, USA). The shift in the binding energy due to relative surface charging was corrected using the C1s level at 284.6eV as an internal standard. NH3-TPD and H2-TPR experiments were carried out on a custom-made TCD (thermal conductivity detector) setup. The amount of catalysts used for NH3-TPD and H2-TPR was 100mg and 50mg, respectively. The catalysts were pre-treated in pure He at 400°C for 1h before the experiments. For the NH3-TPD experiments, the catalysts were saturated with anhydrous 4% NH3 in He at a flow rate of 30ml/min for about 30min. Desorption of NH3 was carried out by heating the catalyst from 100 to 800°C in He (50ml/min) at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The H2-TPR experiments were carried out in a 6% H2/N2 flow (30ml/min) after pre-treatment. The temperature was also increased from 100 to 800°C at a rate of 10°C/min. 2.3 Activity measurement CVOCs activity measurements were carried out in a conventional fixed-bed with 0.5g of catalyst in the temperature range of 150–340°C. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 30,000/h. The typical reactant gas composition was 1000ppm CH2Cl2, 10% O2, and balance N2. CH2Cl2 was analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID), whereas CO and CO2 were detected with a FID detector and methanator using nickel catalyst. The DCM conversion was calculated as: (1) X ( % ) = C i n − C o u t C i n × 100 where Cin and Cout are the inlet and outlet concentration (ppm) of DCM, respectively. The CO2 and by-product (CxHyClz) yields (Y) of the tested catalysts were defined as follows: (2) Y ( CO 2 ) ( % ) = C ( CO 2 ) C ( CO 2 ) + C ( CO ) × 100 (3) Y ( C x H y Cl z ) ( % ) = C ( C x H y Cl z ) C in × 100 where C ( CO 2 ) , C ( CO ) , and C ( C x H y Cl z ) are the outlet concentration (ppm) of CO2, CO, and CxHyClz, respectively. The by-products were localized in the reaction tail gas or on the surface of the catalysts, and were difficult to completely detect. In this work, the amount of by-product C ( C x H y Cl z ) was calculated from the carbon balance, expressed as: [ C i n − C o u t − C ( C O 2 ) − C ( C O ) ] . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure The XRD pattern of the as-prepared catalysts (Fig. 1 )showed several strong reflections from the anatase phase of TiO2 (JCPDS file 21–1272) [26,27]. In addition to the desired phase, some small reflections from noble metals or noble metal oxides were also observed, namely, PdO for the Pd/TiO2 catalyst, Pt for Pt/TiO2, and RuO2 for Ru/TiO2, corresponding to JCPDS 43–1024 [28], 04-0802 [13] and 43–10271 [29], respectively. Fig. 2 shows the N2 absorption-desorption isotherms and corresponding pore size distributions of TiO2 and the noble-metal-loaded TiO2 samples. According to the IUPAC classification [30–32], the isotherm of the TiO2 sample was a typical Type IV with type H2 hysteresis loop. This indicated the presence of mesopores, which was also confirmed from the scanning electron micrographs (SEM). As shown in Fig. S1, the TiO2 sample comprised a coral-like network of aggregated particles, resulting in fully interconnected mesopores. The pore size distribution curves (Fig. 2b) revealed a bimodal distribution of the mesopores in the TiO2 sample (2–5 and 10–30nm). The pores in the size range of 2−5nm are likely to be the internal porosity in the particles, and those with a size of 10−30nm might be formed by particle stacking. The addition of noble metals induced little change in the structure of TiO2. The bimodal mesoporous structures were also maintained, as shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b). There was no significant difference in the SEM images of the four catalysts. However, as seen in Fig. 2(b), the pores in the size range of 10–30nm varied to some extent. The pore-size distribution of the Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts were similar and were larger than those of TiO2. This phenomenon was more obvious for the Ru/TiO2 catalyst and the larger pores had dimensions of 15–40nm. The BET specific areas of the Pd/TiO2, Pt/TiO2, and Ru/TiO2 catalysts were estimated to be 93, 88 and 71m2/g, respectively. 3.2 NH3-TPD and H2-TPR The acidic properties play an important role in the adsorption of DCM and its subsequent combustion, and could be evaluated by NH3-TPD (Fig. 3 ). A distinct NH3 desorption peak was observed at 250°C with two shoulders at 580 and 750°C for the Pd/TiO2 catalyst. These peaks indicated that the catalyst comprised numerous low and medium acidic sites and a small number of strong acidic sites. Only one strong and broad desorption peak was observed in the range of 100–650°C in the NH3-TPD curve of Pt/TiO2. The intensity of the peak was similar to that of the Pd/TO2 catalyst, whereas the peak maximum shifted to higher temperature, suggesting that the sample contained a large number of medium and strong acidic sites. For the Ru/TiO2 catalyst, NH3 desorption peaks were observed at 320°C and 630°C. The calculated total acidity of the catalysts (Table S2) followed the order: Pd/TiO2 >Pt/TiO2> Ru/TiO2. H2-TPR was employed to further investigate the redox ability of all the samples, which is an important factor affecting the catalytic reaction. Fig. 4 showed the H2-TPR profiles of the three catalysts from 50 to 800°C. For the Pd/TiO2 catalyst, a negative H2-consumption peak was observed at 70−80°C due to hydrogen spillover, which is frequently encountered in Pd-containing catalysts [33]. The next small peak at 270°C was attributed to the reduction of the PdO species that were not reduced at room temperature. The third broad but weak peak was attributed to the reduction of Pd species and the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+. It should be noted that the distinct peak below 50°C is attributed to the reduction of small palladium oxide particles that might exist on the surface of the catalyst [34,35]. Only weak H2 consumption peaks were observed for the Pt/TiO2 catalyst, probably due to the low Pt loading. The first one was observed 50°C and could be assigned to the reduction of Pt species. The other was a broad peak spanning 250–700°C, which might be attributed to the reduction of Pt species and some Ti4+ present in titania. The peak for H2 consumption on Pt/TiO2 was weak, as is generally observed for other Pt based catalysts [36]. A broad and large reduction profile composed of three peaks from 50 to 210°C was observed for the Ru/TiO2 catalyst, implying that the ruthenium oxides were reduced in several steps [37,38]. Another broad and large reduction peak appeared from 300 to 700°C and could be assigned to the enhanced reduction of the TiO2 support through spillover of hydrogen species from Ru onto TiO2. Notably, the intensity of the peaks in the TPR profile of the Ru/TiO2 catalyst was much stronger than those of that Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts, which suggested that the Ru/TiO2 catalyst was more easily reduced. 3.3 DCM activity Fig. 5 (a) shows the DCM conversion over the three different catalysts. The Pd/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity for decomposition of DCM, and DCM was completely decomposed at 335°C. Ru/TiO2 exhibited the lowest catalytic activity below 240°C, but its activity increased abruptly as the temperature was further increased. When the temperature exceeded 275°C, the DCM conversion was almost the same as that of Pd/TiO2. The initial reaction temperature of Pt/TiO2 was higher than that of Pd/TiO2 and lower than that of Ru/TiO2. However, the catalytic activity increased slowly with increasing temperature and only reached 47% at 335°C. Compared to other catalytic systems, such as Pt/Al2O3 and Cr-O/HZSM-5 [39,40], Ru/TiO2 and Pd/TiO2 exhibited similar or even better DCM conversion. It has been reported that the DCM decomposes into CO, CO2, and C-containing by-products (CxHyClz) [41]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), trace amounts of by-products were detected and the ratio was less than 10% over the entire temperature range for the three catalysts. For the Pd/TiO2 and Ru/TiO2 catalysts, no by-products were observed at 335°C. In the lower temperature region, CO was the dominant product and the order of CO production with the tested catalysts in this case was: Pd/TiO2 < Ru/TiO2 < Pt/TiO2. With an increase in the reaction temperature, the production of CO decreased and CO2 was dominant in the outlet gas. The CO2 yield reached 100% at 315°C for Ru/TiO2 and at 335°C for Pd/TiO2. Pt/TiO2 was an exception in that it still produced CO as a final incomplete oxidation production. According to the literatures, the surface acid sties and reducibility of the catalysts are two main factors influencing the DCM oxidation performance [10,42]. The surface acid sites are generally considered as the catalytically active sites for DCM decomposition, especially for the rupture of CCl bonds. The reducibility at lower temperature is beneficial for the decomposition of the reactants and byproducts produced during DCM oxidation and is therefore related to the selectivity for formation of the byproducts and CO2. The DCM conversion capability followed the order: Pd/TiO2 >Pt/TiO2> Ru/TiO2 below 240°C, which is in accordance with the order of the surface acid sties of the three catalysts. However, the conversion over Pt/TiO2 did not increase as expected, implying deactivation of the catalyst, which is discussed later in this text. The Pd/TiO2 catalyst showed high selectivity for CO2 in the lower temperature range due to its better low-temperature reducibility, indicted by a distinct reduction peak below 50°C. Above 300°C, the Ru/TiO2 catalyst exhibited better CO2 selectivity than the Pd/TiO2 catalyst and almost total oxidation of CO to CO2 was achieved because of the greater reducibility of this catalyst in the high-temperature range, as suggested by H2-TPR. On the other hand, the poor deep oxidation of DCM over Pt/TiO2 could be explained by the poor reducibility of this catalyst. 3.4 Stability for DCM oxidation The long-term stability of the catalysts for DCM oxidation was evaluated at 315°C. As shown in Fig. 6 , no obvious change in the DCM degradation, CO2 production, and by-product yields was observed for the reaction over the Ru/TiO2 catalyst after 6h. The DCM conversion also remained stable at 97% for the reaction over the Pd/TiO2 catalyst. However, there was a detectable deterioration in the selectivity, in that the CO2 yield decreased from 95% to 91% and the amount of by-products increased from 0.7% to 3%. Pt/TiO2 showed the lowest stability. The DCM conversion and the oxidation of CO decreased obviously and more by-products were generated. It is well known that the pore structure of a catalyst significantly influences the VOC dynamic adsorption/desorption performance and the diffusion of gaseous reactants and products [19]. For the Ru/TiO2 catalyst, the pore-size distribution of 15−40nm was larger than that of the other catalysts. From the long-term stability test results, it could be inferred that the larger pore-size distribution might favorable influence the superior stability of Ru/TiO2 for DCM oxidation. To further explore the possible reasons for the difference in the catalytic activity and stability of the three catalysts, the fresh catalysts and the used catalysts after DCM decomposition at 315°C for 6h were characterized by XRD and XPS. XRD analysis (Fig. 7 ) suggested that the framework of the TiO2 support for the three catalysts was preserved, evidencing the relatively good structural stability of the samples. However, for Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2, the peaks of PdO and Pt disappeared after the DCM oxidation experiment. XPS measurements were carried out to determine the surface chemical composition and chemical states of the samples before and after use for DCM decomposition. The surface atomic concentrations of the catalysts were calculated and are shown in Tables S3−6. Fig. 8 (a) shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of the C1s regions of all the samples, where the C1s peaks could be fitted to three peaks at binding energies of 284.6, 286.1, and 288.5eV, attributed to CC bonds, CO bonds and, CO bonds, respectively [43,44]. In the case of the fresh catalysts, a broad peak was observed at 284.6eV with two small peaks at 286.1 and 288.5eV, assigned to carbon species adsorbed on the surface of the fresh catalysts as a contaminant. For the used catalysts, the peaks from 290.5 to 282.5eV became broader and more intense than those of the fresh catalysts. More specifically, the intensity of the peak at 284.6eV decreased. The intensity of the peak at 286.1eV increased distinctly and this became the main peak. Meanwhile, the intensity of the peak at 288.5eV increased along with that of the main peaks. This suggested that more adventitious carbon species were adsorbed on the surface of the used catalysts, such as carbonate species and carboxylate species. Van den Brink et al. [45] reported that the DCM oxidation over Al2O3 occurred by the following pathway: chemisorbed formaldehyde was formed and then disproportionated to form surface methoxy and formate groups that were further converted to CH3Cl and CO or CO2. Therefore, the carbon species on the surface of the used catalysts are very likely to be generated from the deposition of intermediate products of DCM oxidation, in addition to the contaminants. Moreover, the former was the primary cause, given that the peak at around 286.1eV was the main peak compared with that of the fresh catalyst for which the main peak occurred at 286.4eV. The CO/CC (Table S3) ratio for the three catalysts followed the order: Pd/TiO2 > Pt/TiO2 > Ru/TiO2. This implies that the deposition of carbon species was favored on the Pd/TiO2 catalyst followed by the Pt/TiO2 catalyst. The deposition of carbon species on the surface of Ru/TiO2 was relatively difficult. This may be related to the larger pore-size distribution of Ru/TiO2, which is favorable for the desorption of by-products during the DCM oxidation process. For the Pt/TiO2 catalyst, the DCM conversion was only 44% at 315°C and the intermediate products decreased accordingly. It is comprehensible that less deposition of carbon species occurred on Pt/TiO2 than on Pd/TiO2. Considering the decreased DCM conversion and selectivity for by-products and CO2 of the Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts in the long-term stability test, it is proposed that the deposition of carbon species may be one of the causes of deactivation of the catalysts during DCM oxidation. The XPS spectra in the O1s region for the fresh and used samples are shown in Fig. 8(b). According to previous reports, there are typically two kinds of surface oxygen: lattice oxygen at lower binding energy (529.0–531.0eV), and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oad) at 531.0–534.0eV, such as chemisorbed oxygen (O2 2− and O−), hydroxyl, and oxygen in the metal oxides [35,46]. For the fresh catalysts, a broad peak was observed that was mainly attributed to lattice oxygen, for example Ti-O and M-O (M=Pd, Pt, or Ru). For the used catalysts, another peak emerged at 532.7eV, assigned to surface-adsorbed oxygen. This peak was even stronger than that of lattice oxygen for Pd/TiO2, which further confirmed the deposition of carbon species. Fig. 8(c) shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of the Cl2p region for all the samples, with a peak at 198.2eV [26]. In the process of catalyst preparation, all the precursors of the noble metal oxides contained Cl species. After calcination, no Cl species were detected for the fresh Ru/TiO2 catalyst, whereas for the Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts, a small Cl2p peak was observed, implying that the Cl species could not be totally removed in the preparation process. For the used Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts, the intensity of the Cl2p peak increased, suggesting that a large amount of Cl species accumulated on the surface of the catalysts and could not be removed at 315°C. In contrast, only a small amount of Cl species was observed on the surface of the used Ru/TiO2 catalyst based on the small Cl2p peaks in Fig. 8(c). According to previous reports, RuO2-based catalysts are widely used in the Deacon process as the oxidation of Cl into molecular chlorine (Cl2) was facilitated by only the RuO2 component [47]. Ran [17] et al. also reported that the highly stable activity of Ru/TiO2 for catalytic combustion of chlorinated aromatics was related to the efficient removal of Cl species. Thus, it could be concluded that the high stability of Ru/TiO2 in this work was partly due to its high resistance to Cl poisoning. However, the dissociated Cl adsorbed on the surface of Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts could not be removed rapidly at 315°C. Instead, these species covered the active sites and led to decreased DCM conversion and selectivity for the by-products and CO2. Fig. 5(a) shows that the DCM conversion on Pt/TiO2 was relatively high at low temperature but increased slowly with increasing temperature. In the long-term stability test, the decrease in the DCM conversion and selectivity of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst was more obvious than for the Pd/TiO2 and Ru/TiO2 catalyst. This indicates that the Cl species adsorbed on the surface of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst were more difficult to be removed than those on the other two catalysts. In other words, the Pt/TiO2 catalyst was more sensitive to Cl poisoning. The binding energies of the noble metals on the fresh and used samples are shown in Fig. 8(d–f). The characterization of Ru by XPS is very complicated because the Ru 3d3/2 peak was overlapped with the C 1s peak at 284.8eV (see inset in Fig. 8d) [48–50]. For the XPS studies, the Ru3d5/2 peak was selected as a representative peak. This peak could be fitted to two peaks at binding energies of 279.9eV and 279.2eV, corresponding to the RuO2 nanoparticles (Ru(4+)) and the metallic Ru nanoparticles (Ru(0)), respectively. These results implied that the two kinds of crystalline phases of Ru were coexistent, with the oxidized species being dominant, which agrees well with the XRD results. RuO2 species are generally considered as redox centers and favor the removal of carbon and Cl species [47]. After use for DCM oxidation, the intensity of the Ru(0) peak decreased slightly, probably due to chlorination of Ru(0) to RuCl4 (in contrast with the ratio of Ru(4+)/Ru(0) in Table S4). However, the overall profile of the Ru3d5/2 peak changed little compared with that of the fresh catalyst, which suggested that the chemical states of Ru remained stable during the process of DCM oxidation. In the XPS spectra of the Pd 3d region, all of the samples displayed a typical doublet peak, attributed to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2. The Pd 3d5/2 peak could be fitted to three main doublets at 335.3, 337.1, and 338.5eV, assigned to Pd(0), Pd(2+), and Pd(4+), respectively [51,52]. The presence of Pd(0), Pd(2+), and Pd(4+) is the evidence of metallic Pd, PdO, and the possible chemistry PdO2 [53]. In the present work, the Cl2p peak was observed on fresh sample. Therefore, PdCl2 or PdCl4 might also be presence. The surface atomic concentrations of the three different types of Pd species on the Pd/TiO2 catalyst are shown in Table S5. For the used Pd/TiO2, the percentage of Pd(0) and Pd(2+) decreased and the amount of Pd(4+) increased, plausibly due to the deposition of Cl species and the generation of PdCl4. Three doublet peaks (4f5/2 and 4f7/2) of Pt were observed in the XPS spectrum of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst, i.e., Pt(4+) at 77.5 and 74.2eV, Pt(2+) at 75.5 and 72.5eV, and Pt(0) at 74.9 and 71.4eV [36,54]. Metallic Pt particles could be generated on the oxide surface from calcination of the Pt chloride precursor at higher temperatures. Therefore, a certain amount of Pt(0) was generated on the fresh sample, as also confirmed by XRD characterization. According to the previous reports, the presence of Pt(2+) seemed to be unusual, where divalent platinum is very likely to be produced from Pt(4+) during work-up of the XPS sample [26]. The chemical state of Pt(4+) might exist as a mixture of PtO2 and PtCl4 due to the presence of Cl species on the fresh sample. After being used in the DCM decomposition experiment, the ratio of Pt(4+)/Pt(0) (Table S6) increased, implying that the metallic Pt was chloridized to PtCl4. Michalik-Zym [33] reported that the dominant form of surface palladium on the Pd/Ti-PILC catalyst was Pd2+ and the catalyst showed excellent performance in the combustion of DCM. For benzyl alcohol oxidation, metallic Pd species were often found to be more active than the oxide forms of palladium and were regarded as the active species [52]. On the other hand, it is well known that Pt(0) species are active centers for the complete oxidation of toluene to CO2 and H2O [55]. Generally, the formation of metallic species (Pd, Pt) or the oxides of low valence states Pd(2+) is beneficial for catalytic reactions on Pd- or Pt- containing catalysts, as is the case for DCM combustion. During the DCM decomposition process, the Cl species that were dissociated from CH2Cl2 accumulated on the surface of the catalysts, leading to a change in the chemical states of the Pd or Pt species. The proportion of metallic Pd (the oxides of low valence states Pd(2+)) or Pt decreased and the surface atomic ratios of Pd(4+)/(Pd(0)+ Pd(2)) (or Pt(4+)/Pt(0)) increased, resulting in the deterioration of the DCM conversion and selectivity of Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, Ru/TiO2 was effective for the oxidation of CH2Cl2 and exhibited stable DCM removal activity in a long-term stability test. The Pd/TiO2 catalyst exhibited better DCM conversion and deep oxidation to CO2 at the beginning of the experiment, but was prone to deactivation, leading to a decrease in the selectivity for CO2 and the deep oxidation capability. The Pt/TiO2 catalyst was quickly deactivated and showed poor capability for DCM decomposition. Deactivation of the Pd/TiO2 and Pt/TiO2 catalysts was attributed to the deposition of carbon species and chlorine poisoning, as verified by XPS characterization. On one hand, the deposition of carbon and chlorine species could cover the active sites for DCM decomposition, whereas, on the other hand, the adsorption of chlorine species resulted in the generation of inactive chemical states of Pd or Pt species. The Ru/TiO2 catalyst favored the removal of carbon and Cl species, thus deactivation was inhibited. Furthermore, the larger pore-size distribution of Ru/TiO2 was favorable for the desorption of by-products during the oxidation process of DCM. coredata.dc:description: Pt-, Pd-, and Ru-doped bimodal mesoporous TiO2 catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation and applied to the catalytic combustion of dichloromethane (DCM). The Pd/TiO2 and Ru/TiO2 catalysts exhibited excellent catalytic activity. Total oxidation of DCM was obtained at 335°C with less undesired CO and byproducts (CxHyClz). A certain decrease in the selectivity of the Pd/TiO2 catalyst was observed in a long-term stability test, whereas Ru/TiO2 displayed appreciable stability. Pt/TiO2 was easily deactivated and showed the poorest performance for DCM decomposition. Deactivation of the catalysts was related to the deposition of carbon species and chlorine poisoning, whereby the active sites for DCM decomposition were occluded. Furthermore, the adsorption of chlorine species could change the chemical states of the Pd or Pt species and generate inactive species. Deactivation of the Ru/TiO2 catalyst was inhibited to some extent as carbon and chlorine species could be removed by RuO2. Moreover, the larger pore-size distribution of Ru/TiO2 was favorable for the desorption of by-products during DCM oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Bimodal mesoporous TiO2 supported Pt, Pd and Ru catalysts and their catalytic performance and deactivation mechanism for catalytic combustion of Dichloromethane (CH2Cl2)
